Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: A Broad Synthesis of Artificial Intelligence and Social Choice

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
Social choice theory is the field that studies the aggregation of individual preferences toward a collective choice. While the artificial intelligence (AI) community has so far played a dominant role in the study of the computational aspects of social choice, the interaction between core AI paradigms and social choice theory has been surprisingly limited.

This project is enhancing the interaction between the two fields through a synthesis of social choice with the following AI areas: (i) decision making under uncertainty, by building on models studied in AI to create new ways to model, analyze, and make decisions in environments where preferences are dynamically changing; (ii) multiagent systems, by studying settings where agents randomly vote over multiple states, and investigating the connection between normative properties and system performance; and finally (iii) machine learning, by employing insights about strategic behavior under structured preferences, developed in the social choice literature, in order to design regression learning algorithms that discourage strategic manipulation.

An overarching goal of this project is to demonstrate the potential of social choice theory to AI researchers, and ultimately to establish social choice theory as a standard paradigm in AI. Equally importantly, this project is expected to increase the scope of social choice theory. Broader impacts include a new web-based voting system, which has the potential to serve and educate hundreds of thousands of users; dissemination through a new book on computational social choice; and a workshop on computational social choice, which will help set a new agenda for the field.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The overarching goal of the project was to make new connections between social choice theory (which deals with the aggregation of individual preferences or opinions into collective decisions) and areas of artificial intelligence such as machine learning, decision making under uncertainty, and multiagent systems.

The research supported by the project led to many significant contributions, including:

1. A new understanding of incentives in machine learning. Specifically, machine learning algorithms that are immune to strategic manipulaiton can be designed by leveraging results from social choice. 

2. A new paradigm for automated decision-making called "virtual democracy." In a nutshell, models of the preferences of stakeholders are learned from data and, when faced with a new dilemma, the preferences of the stakeholders on the dilemma at hand are predicted and aggregated into a decision that is made or recommended by the system. 

3. New techniques for the aggregation of objective opinions in situations where there is a ground truth, including statistical approaches that make minimal assumptions about random noise, and worst-case approaches that make no assumptions whatsoever. 

These results were disseminated through dozens of publications in conferences and journals. The PI also co-edited the Handbook Of Computational Social Choice, published in 2016 by Cambridge University Press, which has become the standard introductory text to the field. 

To make the research supported by the project accessible to the public, the PI led the creation of the not-for-profit website RoboVote.org, whose theme is "AI-driven collective decisions"; it was launched in November 2016. The website offers two types of applications, for the aggregation of subjective preferences and objective opinions. Both applications directly employ research results obtained as part of this project.
